review.title: Fusing Continuous-valued Medical Labels using a Bayesian Model
review.abstract: With the rapid increase in volume of time series medical data available through wearable devices, there is a need to employ automated algorithms to label data. Examples of labels include interventions, changes in activity (e.g. sleep) and changes in physiology (e.g. arrhythmias). However, automated algorithms tend to be unreliable resulting in lower quality care. Expert annotations are scarce, expensive, and prone to significant inter- and intra-observer variance. To address these problems, a Bayesian Continuous-valued Label Aggregator(BCLA) is proposed to provide a reliable estimation of label aggregation while accurately infer the precision and bias of each algorithm. The BCLA was applied to QT interval (pro-arrhythmic indicator) estimation from the electrocardiogram using labels from the 2006 PhysioNet/Computing in Cardiology Challenge database. It was compared to the mean, median, and a previously proposed Expectation Maximization (EM) label aggregation approaches. While accurately predicting each labelling algorithm's bias and precision, the root-mean-square error of the BCLA was 11.78$\pm$0.63ms, significantly outperforming the best Challenge entry (15.37$\pm$2.13ms) as well as the EM, mean, and median voting strategies (14.76$\pm$0.52ms, 17.61$\pm$0.55ms, and 14.43$\pm$0.57ms respectively with $p<0.0001$).

metadata.title: Fusing Continuous-valued Medical Labels using a Bayesian Model

sections.text: There is a need to use automated algorithms to label data. Examples of labels include interventions, changes in activity (e.g. sleep), and changes in physiology (e.g. arrhythmias). However, automated algorithms tend to be unreliable, resulting in lower quality care. Expert comments are rare, expensive, and tend to cause significant discrepancies between observers. To solve these problems, it is proposed to use a Bayesian Continuous Value Label Aggregator (BCLA) that provides a reliable assessment of label aggregation while accurately deriving the accuracy and bias of each algorithm. BCLA was applied to the QT Interval (pro-arrhythmic Indicator) estimate from the electrocardiogram using labels from the PhysioNet / Computing in Cardiology Challenge database of 2006. It was used with the mean, the median and a previously proposed 2006 Electrocardiogram expectation database of electrocardiogram (EM) in the Electrocardiogram.

sections.heading: 2 Materials and Methods
sections.text: 2.1 Bayesian Continuous-rated Label Aggregator (BCLA) 1) Here is the deviation from the norm. Suppose there are N datasets of physiological time series labeled by R annotators. Leave D = [xi, y = R i] N = 1, where xi is a column attribute for the dataset containing d features (i.e. the design matrix, X = [x1,..., x N]), y ji corresponds to the annotation provided by the ith dataset, and zi represents the unknown underlying truth (the true time or duration of an event, for example).The graphical representation of the proposed approach - the Bayesian Continuous-rated Label Aggregator (BCLA) - is provided in Fig. 2.In this model, y ji is assumed to be a noisy version of zi, with a Gaussian distribution N (y i).

sections.heading: 2.4.1 Simulated data set
sections.text: To test the reliability of the BCLA as a generative model, a simulated dataset was created: a total of 548 simulated datasets were created, each with 20 independent annotations, giving a total of 10,960 annotations (see Fig. 3). The simulated dataset assumed that annotators had precision values λ (i.e. 1 / 270 m ²) drawn from the average (4.0003 m ²), assuming that the annotations of the most powerful annotator were ± 15 ms away from the basic truth. Annotators were drawn from N (10.25), a Gaussian distribution with a mean of 10 ms and a standard deviation (1 / 2 b) of 25 ms. In addition, the true annotation for each dataset was assumed to be drawn from N (400.40), a Gaussian distribution with an average of 400 ms and a standard deviation (1 / 2 b) of 40 ms.

sections.heading: 2.4.2 Real data set
sections.text: The data was collected by the participants in the PhysioNet / Computing in Cardiology (PCinC) challenge (15) for the identification of QT intervals related to Lead II in each of the 548 records in the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt Diagnostische ECG-Database (PTBDB). Records were obtained from 290 subjects (209 men with an average age of 55.5 years and 81 women with an average age of 61.6 years), in which 20% of the subjects were healthy controls. An example of QT interval is shown in Fig. 1 (c). The PTBDB database included recordings of patients with a variety of ECG morphologies with different QT intervals from 256 to 529 ms. Diagnostic classifications of ECG morphologies mainly included myocardial infarction, heart failure, bundle-branch block and dysrhythmia, as in Bousselet categories of gyroscopes and two main categories [There were].

sections.heading: 3 Results
sections.text: The convergence of the BCLA model is guaranteed by setting a threshold using the GEVD as stop criteria (see Eqn (13). In the real data collection, the upper limit of precision derived from the GEVD is each represented as 0.04, based on the assumption that the best performance annotator is ± 5ms away from the reference. The number of iterations depends on the number of datasets and the number of annotations. To illustrate the practical usefulness of our model, it took 7.55 seconds for the BCLA to perform 5,000 iterations taking into account a total of 20.712 annotations (Division 2) using MATLAB R2011a on a 2.2GHz Intel (R) i7-2670QM processor. Approximately 2,500 iterations were needed to stabilize all parameters.3.1 Simulated data setFig. 4 (a) shows an example of the derived BCR-CLA results using the BLA and the BR-CR-CLA results

sections.heading: 4 Discussion

An effective probabilistic approach to aggregating expert labels which used an Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm, was first proposed by Dawid and Skene [6].
[16] extended this approach to measure the diameter of a suspicious lesion on a medical image using a regression model.

Welinder and Perona [23] proposed a Bayesian EM framework for continuous-valued labels, which explicitly modelled the precision only of each annotator to account for their varying skill levels, without modelling the bias of annotators.

The methodology proposed in the work presented in this article improves on these prior algorithms [16, 22, 23] by introducing the novelty of combining continuous-valued annotations to infer the underlying ground truth, while jointly modelling the annotator’s bias and precision in an unified model using a Bayesian treatment.

The QT interval is one particular measure of ECG morphology, and refers to the elapsed time between the onset of ventricular depolarisation (the QRS complex) and the T wave offset (ventricular repolarisation) [4].

[19] presented the ECGs recorded from two patients with long QT syndrome (LQTS) and from two healthy females to 902 physicians (25 QT experts who had published on the subject, 106 arrhythmia specialists, 329 cardiologists, and 442 noncardiologists) from 12 countries.

metadata.abstractText: With the rapid increase in volume of time series medical data available through wearable devices, there is a need to employ automated algorithms to label data. Examples of labels include interventions, changes in activity (e.g. sleep) and changes in physiology (e.g. arrhythmias). However, automated algorithms tend to be unreliable resulting in lower quality care. Expert annotations are scarce, expensive, and prone to significant interand intra-observer variance. To address these problems, a Bayesian Continuous-valued Label Aggregator(BCLA) is proposed to provide a reliable estimation of label aggregation while accurately infer the precision and bias of each algorithm. The BCLA was applied to QT interval (pro-arrhythmic indicator) estimation from the electrocardiogram using labels from the 2006 PhysioNet/Computing in Cardiology Challenge database. It was compared to the mean, median, and a previously proposed Expectation Maximization (EM) label aggregation approaches. While accurately predicting each labelling algorithm’s bias and precision, the root-mean-square error of the BCLA was 11.78±0.63ms, significantly outperforming the best Challenge entry (15.37±2.13ms) as well as the EM, mean, and median voting strategies (14.76±0.52ms, 17.61±0.55ms, and 14.43±0.57ms respectively with p < 0.0001). The BCLA could therefore provide accurate estimation for medical continuous-valued label tasks in an unsupervised manner even when the ground truth is not available.
